title: 35 years of product design wisdom from Apple, Disney, Pinterest and beyond | Bob Baxley
themes: Apollo program lessons for product teams
key_insights: Design should report to engineering to ensure better integration and implementation, treating design as phase zero of the engineering process
Wait as long as possible to draw pictures or create prototypes to avoid the 'primal mark' problem where teams gravitate toward the first visual solution
Design tenets (decision-making tools) are more valuable than design principles (platitudes) - they should help resolve recurring debates
Software is a medium that elicits emotional responses, and builders have a moral obligation to put positive emotional energy into people's lives
Company culture around design must exist from the founding DNA - it cannot be grafted on later
Give designers clear constraints and context (like a detailed AI prompt) to enable faster, more focused work
Small teams (4-24 people) are optimal for creating breakthrough products - larger teams struggle with scenius and coherent vision
When changing companies, hold onto values but adapt behaviors to fit the new culture

guest_background.current_role: Design advisor and mentor (recently at ThoughtSpot)

topics_discussed: Steve Jobs' perspective on Apple as his greatest product
Why Apple alumni often struggle at other companies
Bob's unsuccessful experience at Pinterest and lessons learned
Design reporting structure and organizational dynamics
Software as an emotional medium vs. just a tool
Design principles vs. design tenets for decision-making
The moral obligation to build great products
Apollo program and John Houbolt's lunar orbit rendezvous story
Why you should delay creating high-fidelity prototypes
Company vision and its impact on design efficiency
The importance of small teams for breakthrough innovation
Using AI as a life coach and reflection tool

Space exploration lessons for product development
memorable_quotes: Design is trying to imagine the future you want to live in and then take the steps to make it real.
We have an obligation as product people to put that emotional energy back into people's lives.
Saying a company is design-led does not mean it's designer-led.
frameworks_mentioned: Block brain diagrams for low-fidelity ideation
Lunar Orbit Rendezvous as a metaphor for elegant solutions
The Beatles team size principle (4-24 people optimal)
recommended_for: product managers working with design teams
senior designers transitioning to leadership roles
anyone interested in product philosophy and ethics
summary: Bob Baxley shares 35 years of product design wisdom from Apple, Pinterest, and other top companies, covering everything from organizational structure and team dynamics to the moral obligation of building great software. He provides counterintuitive insights on design leadership, including why design should report to engineering and why you should delay creating prototypes, while emphasizing that software is a powerful emotional medium that requires thoughtful stewardship.
